website_meta.title: Dark Patterns: Unveiling Manipulation
website_meta.tagline: Exposing the Subtle Art of Influence in Digital & Human Realms

patterns.name: Forced Continuity
patterns.description: When free trials automatically convert to paid subscriptions without clear warning or easy cancellation.
patterns.how_to_spot: Look for vague trial terms or difficult cancellation flows.

patterns.name: Confirmshaming
patterns.description: Guilting users into opting into something by shaming them if they decline.
patterns.how_to_spot: Phrases like 'No thanks, I prefer to pay full price' for a discount.

patterns.title: Autoplay Next Episode
patterns.description: Automatically playing the next episode to keep users engaged for longer periods.
patterns.user_impact: Can lead to binge-watching and excessive screen time.

patterns.title: Infinite Scroll
patterns.description: A feed that continuously loads new content as the user scrolls, preventing a natural stopping point.
patterns.user_impact: Contributes to addiction and prolonged usage.

patterns.title: Fake Notifications
patterns.description: Notifications designed to create a sense of urgency or social obligation that are not genuinely critical.
patterns.user_impact: Drives users back to the app unnecessarily.

techniques.name: Gaslighting
techniques.description: Manipulating someone into questioning their own reality, memory, or sanity.
techniques.how_to_recognize: Constant denial of events you clearly remember, 'You're crazy,' 'That never happened.'

techniques.name: Fear of Missing Out (FOMO)
techniques.description: Creating anxiety that one might miss out on something desirable or important if they don't act.
techniques.how_to_recognize: Phrases like 'Limited time offer!', 'Everyone else is doing it!'

biases.name: Confirmation Bias
biases.explanation: The tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms one's preexisting beliefs.
biases.exploitation: Manipulators feed you information that aligns with your views, making their narrative more believable.
biases.example: Only reading news sources that confirm your political views.

biases.name: Anchoring Bias
biases.explanation: The tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information offered (the 'anchor') when making decisions.
biases.exploitation: Presenting an extreme initial offer to make subsequent, slightly less extreme offers seem reasonable.
biases.example: A high initial price for a product making a 'discounted' price seem like a good deal.

biases.name: Bandwagon Effect
biases.explanation: The tendency to do or believe things because many other people do or believe the same, regardless of the underlying evidence.
biases.exploitation: Highlighting popularity ('Millions have tried it!'), creating social pressure.
biases.example: Buying a product just because it's a 'bestseller.'
